projects.heading: Designing graphs for smal screens
projects.subheading: Optimizing Data Visualization for an Electrical Consumption App
projects.introduction: When designing a mobile-friendly energy consumption graph, several key decisions shaped the final outcome:

sections.title: Overview
sections.content: One of the key pages in an electrical consumption app is where users can monitor their energy usage and costs. While users want insights into their consumption habits across different time periods—ranging from hourly to yearly—electricity companies also aim to help them recognize patterns and adjust their behaviors. This presents a design challenge: how can we create a clear, accessible, and engaging graph that serves both perspectives while remaining easy to use on small screens?

sections.title: 1. Choosing the Right Graph Type
sections.content: After exploring several options, we settled on a step graph as the most suitable choice. It blends the advantages of line and bar graphs, providing clarity and a more interactive experience without misrepresenting the data.
steps: A line graph implies continuous data, which is inaccurate when visualizing hourly electricity readings.
A bar graph can feel rigid and harder to navigate, especially on mobile.
A step graph offers a clear and intuitive representation of discrete hourly values, making patterns easy to spot.

sections.title: 2. Improving Data Readability on Mobile
sections.content: Traditional tooltips often obstruct the view and are tricky to use on touchscreens. To solve this, we implemented large, fixed-position data values that remain visible without interaction, ensuring that key information is easily accessible even when navigating with thumbs.

sections.title: 3.  Comparing Different Data Types Without Overload
sections.content: Users needed to compare both electricity consumption (kWh) and cost per kWh within the same graph. However, multi-variable graphs risk becoming overwhelming. To balance clarity and functionality:
steps: We introduced dual Y-axes with matching visual styles.
Users can choose to toggle comparison data, keeping the default view simple for less advanced users while still enabling deeper insights for those who want them.

sections.title: 4. Enhancing Readability Through Visual Design
steps: The main consumption line features a subtle gradient to give it depth without distraction.
Comparison lines use a white border to remain distinct even when colors overlap, without introducing additional gradients or noise.
Color choices were made with accessibility in mind, ensuring that all users — including those with color vision deficiencies — can clearly interpret the data.
Additionally, to ensure accessibility for users with color vision deficiencies, we introduced small graphical markers (circles and squares) on both the graph lines and the corresponding data labels.

sections.title: 5. The date picker for the graph
sections.content: We also designed a date picker tailored for mobile use, enabling users to easily switch between day, week, month, and year views. It adapts seamlessly to small screens and allows users to explore historical data without friction.

Instead, I’ve built this portfolio to reflect my passion for simplicity, clarity, and functionality.

sections.title: Overview
sections.content: This webpage is a space where you can get a quick and honest impression of who I am and the work I do. I’ve focused on keeping the design simple and intuitive, avoiding excessive CSS animations —but I couldn't resist adding a playful SVG animation of a logo.

sections.title: Design Process
sections.content: I have designed this page naturally, drawing inspiration from others and selecting elements that align with my three guiding principles: simplicity, clarity, and efficiency.
steps: Efficiency: While I would love for my readers to learn everything about me, I respect their valuable time and aim to deliver key insights quickly.
Clarity: I want visitors to get a quick glimpse of my work fast enough to capture interest but slow enough to intrigue leaving them wanting to know more.
Simplicity: To be kind to the developer, which happens to be me

sections.title: Creating the webb page, using React
sections.content: Every part of this portfolio is built using React and Next.js. Building this portfolio has been a learning journey, where I’ve honed my skills in React while keeping the design and functionality aligned with my principles of simplicity, clarity, and efficiency.

projects.heading: Interactive Visualization of Climate Change in the OpenSpace Project
projects.subheading: Master’s Thesis, Linköping University at New York University (2022)

sections.title: Overview
sections.content: For my master’s thesis, I designed and developed an interactive graphical user interface (GUI) to visualize climate change on Earth’s surface, with a specific focus on the melting glaciers of Antarctica. This project was part of the international OpenSpace initiative, a collaboration involving universities, research institutions, and NASA.

sections.title: Design Process
sections.content: The project followed an iterative design methodology to create a user-friendly interface that communicates complex scientific data to the general public. I conducted in-depth research to better understand the challenges and user needs related to climate visualization. This process involved close collaboration with climate experts and stakeholders to refine the project’s focus and ensure relevance. Additionally, I developed wireframes and prototypes in Figma, which were iteratively tested to explore and validate interaction concepts.
steps: Story-driven exploration: Users could follow an engaging narrative to learn about climate change, transitioning between global trends and localized impacts.
Interactive controls: Time sliders, visual overlays, and color-coded indicators allowed users to explore datasets intuitively.
Open-world mode: Users could freely explore climate data globally, discovering patterns and correlations on their own terms.

sections.title: Development
sections.content: The technical implementation involved programming the GUI in React and integrating it with OpenSpace’s C++ backend using a custom-built API.
steps: Transformed multidimensional satellite datasets into OpenSpace-compatible formats using Python.
Handled datasets such as global ocean currents, ice melt trends, and gravity field measurements.
Enabled smooth transitions between local and global visualizations, ensuring accessibility for non-expert users.

sections.title: Outcome
sections.content: The final product was tested with seven users from varied backgrounds, including climate experts and non-specialists, yielding valuable insights for refinement. Feedback confirmed that the application succeeded in making complex climate data more understandable and engaging.
